Constructor Detail

FireEagleConsumer

public FireEagleConsumer(java.lang.String key,
                         java.lang.String secret)
Creates a new instance of FireEagleConsumer

Parameters:
key - The consumer key for your Fire Eagle application
secret - The consumer secret for yout Fire Eagle application
Method Detail

fetchNewRequestToken

public RequestToken fetchNewRequestToken()
                                  throws OAuthServiceProviderException
Makes an HTTPS call to Fire Eagle to get a request token NOTE: this makes a synchronous HTTPS connection, which might make J2ME unhappy if you don't deal with threading elsewhere. (The example midlet works around this by running UI stuff in a new thread so that network requests can be made from the main thread.)

Returns:
a RequestToken object -- you'll need to display the token portion to the user
Throws:
OAuthServiceProviderException

fetchNewAccessToken

public AccessToken fetchNewAccessToken()
                                throws OAuthServiceProviderException,
                                       BadTokenStateException
Makes an HTTPS call to Fire Eagle to get an access token NOTE: this makes a synchronous HTTPS connection, which might make J2ME unhappy if you don't deal with threading elsewhere. (The example midlet works around this by running UI stuff in a new thread so that network requests can be made from the main thread.) Also note this method doesn't take a parameter, FireEagleConsumer will remember the request token it fetched

Returns:
an AccessToken object -- you'll need to display the token portion to the user
Throws:
OAuthServiceProviderException
BadTokenStateException

updateLocation

public java.lang.String updateLocation(java.util.Hashtable queryParams)
                                throws OAuthServiceProviderException,
                                       BadTokenStateException,
                                       java.io.IOException
Makes an HTTPS call to Fire Eagle to update location NOTE: this makes a synchronous HTTPS connection, which might make J2ME unhappy if you don't deal with threading elsewhere. (The example midlet works around this by running UI stuff in a new thread so that network requests can be made from the main thread.)

Parameters:
queryParams - a Hashtable with key-value pairs representing a location, e.g. postal=94707
Returns:
a String (usually XML) containing Fire Eagle's response
Throws:
OAuthServiceProviderException
BadTokenStateException
java.io.IOException

queryUserLocation

public java.lang.String queryUserLocation()
                                   throws OAuthServiceProviderException,
                                          BadTokenStateException,
                                          java.io.IOException
Makes an HTTPS call to Fire Eagle to update location NOTE: this makes a synchronous HTTPS connection, which might make J2ME unhappy if you don't deal with threading elsewhere. (The example midlet works around this by running UI stuff in a new thread so that network requests can be made from the main thread.)

Returns:
a String (usually XML) containing Fire Eagle's response
Throws:
OAuthServiceProviderException
BadTokenStateException
java.io.IOException

getRequestToken

public RequestToken getRequestToken()

setAccessToken

public void setAccessToken(AccessToken accessToken)
You'll need this if you're persisting accesss token in a RecordStore or something (probably a good idea), But if you've jsut fetched an AccessToken, FireEagleConsumer will remember it for you

naiveParseErrorResponse

public java.lang.String naiveParseErrorResponse(java.lang.String someXML)
A very feeble XML parser -- looks for the string "msg=" In a real application you should probably add in a real XML parser

naiveParseQueryResponse

public java.lang.String naiveParseQueryResponse(java.lang.String someXML)
A very feeble XML parser -- looks for the <name> tag In a real application you should probably add in a real XML parser
